member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot
member.summary: Plot is a panel that supports positioning of child elements in plot coordinates by providing attached properties X1,Y1,X2,Y2 and Points. Plot panel automatically computes bounding rectangle for all child elements.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.X1Property
member.summary: Identifies the Plot.X1 attached property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.SetX1(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the value of the Plot.X1 attached property for a given dependency object.
member.param: The element to which the property value is written
Sets the Plot.X1 coordinate of the specified element
member.remarks: Infinity values for Plot.X1 are handled is special way. They do not participate in plot bounds computation, “+Infinity” is translated to maximum visible value, “-Infinity” is translated to minimum visible coordinate.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.GetX1(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Returns the value of the Plot.X1 attached property for a given dependency object.
member.param: The element from which the property value is read
member.returns: The Plot.X1 coordinate of the specified element
member.remarks: Default value of Plot.X1 property is Double.NaN. Element is horizontally arranged inside panel according to values of X1 and X2 attached property. X1 and X2 doesn't have to be ordered. If X1 is not specified (has NaN value) than Canvas.Left value is used.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.X2Property
member.summary: Identifies the Plot.X2 attached property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.SetX2(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the value of the Plot.X2 attached property for a given dependency object.
member.param: The element to which the property value is written
Sets the Plot.X2 coordinate of the specified element
member.remarks: Infinity values for Plot.X2 are handled is special way. They do not participate in plot bounds computation, “+Infinity” is translated to maximum visible value, “-Infinity” is translated to minimum visible coordinate.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.GetX2(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Returns the value of the Plot.X2 attached property for a given dependency object.
member.param: The element from which the property value is read
member.returns: The Plot.X2 coordinate of the specified element
member.remarks: Default value of Plot.X2 property is Double.NaN. Element is horizontally arranged inside panel according to values of X1 and X2 attached property. X1 and X2 doesn't have to be ordered. If X2 is not specified (has NaN value) then Width property is used to define element arrangement.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.Y1Property
member.summary: Identifies the Plot.Y1 attached property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.SetY1(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the value of the Plot.Y1 attached property for a given dependency object.
member.param: The element to which the property value is written
Sets the Plot.Y1 coordinate of the specified element
member.remarks: Infinity values for Plot.Y1 are handled is special way. They do not participate in plot bounds computation, “+Infinity” is translated to maximum visible value, “-Infinity” is translated to minimum visible coordinate.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Plot.GetY1(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Returns the value of the Plot.Y1 attached property for a given dependency object.
member.param: The element from which the property value is read
member.returns: The Plot.Y1 coordinate of the specified element

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.MarkerGraph
member.summary:
Displays supplied data series as a collection of markers. Coordinates of marker and its visual properties are defined by different data series (sometimes called variables). Example is scatter plot where two data series X and Y define cartesian coordinates of points on the screen.
Marker graph appearance is defined by three properties: , and . Data series are specified using property.

member.summary: Updates data in data series and starts redrawing marker graph. This method returns before marker graph is redrawn. This method is thread safe.
member.param: List of new values for data series. Elements from are assigned to data series in the order in which data series were defined in XAML or were added to collection.
member.returns: ID of rendering task. You can subscribe to to get notified when marker graph is completely updated.
member.example:
Next code will set two arrays as values of two first data series:
markerGraph.Plot(new int[] { 1,2,3 }, new double[] { -10.0, 0, 20.0 });

member.summary:
Updates data in data series and starts redrawing marker graph. This method returns before marker graph is redrawn. This method is thread safe.
This version does not need specification of X . Default value is a sequence of integers starting with zero.
member.param:
Data for Y defining y coordinates of markers.
Can be a single value (to draw one marker or markers with the same y coordinates) or an array or IEnumerable (to draw markers with different y coordinates) of any numeric type. Can be null then no markers will be drawn.
member.returns: ID of rendering task. You can subscribe to notification about rendering completion events as observer of RenderCompletion.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.CartesianMarkerGraph.PlotXY(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Updates data in data series and starts redrawing marker graph. This method returns before marker graph is redrawn. This method is thread safe.
member.param:
Data for X defining x coordinates of markers.
Can be a single value (to draw one marker or markers with the same x coordinates) or an array or IEnumerable (to draw markers with different x coordinates) of any numeric type. Can be null then x coordinates will be a sequence of integers starting with zero.

Data for Y defining y coordinates of markers.
Can be a single value (to draw one marker or markers with the same y coordinates) or an array or IEnumerable (to draw markers with different y coordinates) of any numeric type. Can be null then no markers will be drawn.
member.remarks: Note that all vector data for should be of the same length. Otherwise no markers will be drawn.
member.returns: ID of rendering task. You can subscribe to notification about rendering completion events as observer of RenderCompletion.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.ErrorBarGraph
member.summary: Displays error bar marker graph as a particular case of . Has a set of additional data series: (key 'C') and (keys 'W' and 'H') to define width (in screen coordinates) and height (in plot coordinates) of each marker.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.ErrorBarGraph.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.ErrorBarGraph.PlotError(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary:
Updates data in data series and starts redrawing marker graph. This method returns before marker graph is redrawn. This method is thread safe.
This version does not need specification of X . Default value is a sequence of integers starting with zero.
member.param:
Data for Y defining y coordinates of the center of each bar.
Can be a single value (to draw one marker or markers with the same y coordinates) or an array or IEnumerable (to draw markers with different y coordinates) of any numeric type. Can be null then no markers will be drawn.

Data for of observation error or the height of each bar.
Can be a single value (to draw markers of one height) or an array or IEnumerable (to draw markers of different heights) of any numeric type. Should be defined in plot coordinates. Can be null then no markers will be drawn.
member.remarks: Note that all vector data for should be of the same length. Otherwise no markers will be drawn.
member.returns: ID of rendering task. You can subscribe to notification about rendering completion events as observer of RenderCompletion.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Palette.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses the palette from the string. See remarks for details.
member.param: A string to parse from.

remarks.para: String can contain: names of colors ( or hexadecimal representation #AARRGGBB), double values and separators (equal symbol or comma) to separate colors and values from each other.
Comma is used for gradient colors, equal symbol - for initializing a color of specified value.
Palette can be normalized or absolute.
Absolute palette maps entire numbers to colors exactly as numbers are specified. For examples, palette '-10=Blue,Green,Yellow,Red=10' maps values -10 and below to Blue, 10 and above to red.
Normalized palette maps minimum value to left palette color, maximum value to right palette color. In normalized palette no numbers on left and right sides are specified.
Palettes can contain regions of constant color. For example, palette 'Blue=0.25=Yellow=0.5=#00FF00=0.75=Orange' maps first quarter of values to blue, second quarter to yellow and so on.

member.returns: A palette that specified string describes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Palette.ToString
member.summary: Gets a string that describes current palette.
member.returns: String that describes palette.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.DynamicDataDisplay.Figure
member.summary: Figure class provides special layout options that are often found in charts. It provides attached property Placement that allows to place child elements in center, left, top, right and bottom slots. Figure override plot-to-screen transform, so that plot coordinates are mapped to the cental part of the Figure.
member.remarks: Figure class provides two-pass algorithm that prevents well-known loop occurring on resize of figure with fixed aspect ratio: figure resize forces update of plot-to-screen transform which adjusts labels on the axes. Change of label size may result in change of central part size which again updates plot-to-screen transform which in turn leads to axes label updates and so on.
